description: From Middle English flum, from Old French flum, flun, from Latin flumen, from fluere (“to flow”).

entries.meaning: A ravine or gorge, usually one with water running through.
An open channel or trough used to direct or divert liquids.

verbs.description: flume (third-person singular simple present flumes, present participle fluming, simple past and past participle flumed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To transport (logs of wood) by floating them along a water-filled channel or trough.
